Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech, which is vital to Australian citizens.
It creates two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educators over ordinary citizens.
Excessive fines will lead to more restrictive digital services, stifling free speech.
The bill's scope is too broad, targeting not only false information but also misleading or deceptive information.
Delegating legislative power to private entities raises constitutional concerns.
The bill assumes government and accredited institutions have sole authority to determine truth, disregarding diverse viewpoints.
Threats to digital platform providers and users promote an oppressive environment.
The bill could categorize political party viewpoints as misinformation, threatening democratic discourse.
Notable Quotes: This bill undermines the freedom of speech that is so vital to Australian citizens.
The bill represents an unconstitutional abdication of parliamentary legislative power.
This bill eliminates the necessary diversity in perspectives, hindering informed decision-making and undermining the very essence of democracy.
